issue.title: Fix stack overflow error in assertIterableEquals

repository.name: junit-framework
repository.description: âœ… The programmer-friendly testing framework for Java and the JVM

issue.body:
## Overview
Prior to this commit an iterable of iterables (here instances of java.nio.file.Path) passed to method `assertIterableEquals` in class `Assertions` of the JUnit Jupiter API yielded a `StackOverflowError`.

This commit prevent the eternal while-loop by leveraging the `equals()`-implementation of the non-null expected element.

Fixes #2157

---

I hereby agree to the terms of the [JUnit Contributor License Agreement](https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/blob/002a0052926ddee57cf90580fa49bc37e5a72427/CONTRIBUTING.md#junit-contributor-license-agreement).

---

### Definition of Done

- [x] There are no TODOs left in the code
- [x] Method [preconditions](https://junit.org/junit5/docs/snapshot/api/org/junit/platform/commons/util/Preconditions.html) are checked and documented in the method's Javadoc
- [x] [Coding conventions](https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#coding-conventions) (e.g. for logging) have been followed
- [x] Change is covered by [automated tests](https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#tests) including corner cases, errors, and exception handling
- [x] Public API has [Javadoc](https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#javadoc) and [`@API` annotations](https://apiguardian-team.github.io/apiguardian/docs/current/api/org/apiguardian/api/API.html)
- [x] Change is documented in the [User Guide](https://junit.org/junit5/docs/snapshot/user-guide/) and [Release Notes](https://junit.org/junit5/docs/snapshot/user-guide/#release-notes)
- [x] All [continuous integration builds](https://github.com/junit-team/junit5#continuous-integration-builds) pass

body: Oh wow, that's a really insidious bug! Thank you very much for finding and fixing it @sormuras. ðŸ‘
I wonder if this bug could have been caught earlier with mutation testing. ðŸ¤”

> I wonder if this bug could have been caught earlier with mutation testing. ðŸ¤”

Interesting thought. Perhaps also a candidate for property-based testing ... @jlink?
@sormuras Can you point me to the test? I'll make it a simple property and see if it catches the bug.

https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/blob/0e393926c537541c00c8bc66e99b198d84c89ab0/junit-jupiter-engine/src/test/java/org/junit/jupiter/api/AssertIterableEqualsAssertionsTests.java#L446-L452

And the one below -- which is expected to fail. With and with the fix.

Edit: Revert this if-clause 

https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/blob/master/junit-jupiter-api/src/main/java/org/junit/jupiter/api/AssertIterableEquals.java#L67-L69

back to

```java
			if (expectedElement == actualElement) {
				continue;
			}
```
This will show the `StackOverflowError` again.

The special thing about path is that its iterator returns paths whose iterator will return instances that are equal to themselves. For instance, the following Groovy snippet 

```groovy
import java.nio.file.Paths
def path = Paths.get("bar");
println path.iterator().next().equals(path)
println path.iterator().next().is(path)
```

prints

```
true
false
```

The code did not account for this kind of recursiveness.
That's some strange kind of behaviour indeed. Nothing in Iterator's contract that would exclude that, though.

issue.title: assertIterableEquals: StackOverflow for self-iterating Iterable
